tools.name: Java
tools.description: Mature JVM language with huge ecosystem and strong enterprise adoption.
whenNotToUse: You need ultra-fast iteration with minimal boilerplate.
Your deployment target has strict memory limits.

guides.title: Project Structure
content: Keep packages aligned with domain boundaries, not tech layers.
Use modules to keep dependencies explicit.

guides.title: Service Layer Patterns
content: Keep services small and focused on orchestration, not data access.
Use immutable DTOs for clarity across layers.

tools.name: C#
tools.description: Modern language with great tooling and strong .NET ecosystem.
whenNotToUse: You need the smallest possible runtime footprint.
Your team is not aligned around .NET.

guides.title: Minimal APIs
content: Start with minimal APIs for small services.
Extract endpoints into dedicated classes as complexity grows.

tools.name: Kotlin
tools.description: Concise JVM language with strong Android and backend support.
whenNotToUse: Your team only knows legacy Java and has zero Kotlin bandwidth.
You need ultra-fast cold starts on serverless.

guides.title: Null Safety
content: Use non-null types by default.
Avoid !! unless you are at the boundary of unsafe data.

tools.name: Haskell
tools.description: Pure functional language focused on correctness and strong types.
whenNotToUse: You need to hire quickly in a broad market.
Your team cannot invest in FP concepts.

guides.title: Type-Driven Design
content: Let types encode business rules early.
Prefer explicit domain types over raw primitives.

code.snippet:
newtype Email = Email String
newtype UserId = UserId Int

tools.name: Elixir
tools.description: Functional language on the BEAM, great for concurrency and reliability.
whenNotToUse: You need a massive off-the-shelf library ecosystem.
You are locked into JVM or .NET infrastructure.

guides.title: Concurrency Basics
content: Use lightweight processes for isolation.
Supervision trees keep systems resilient.

tools.name: Scala
tools.description: Powerful JVM language mixing FP and OOP with strong type system.
whenNotToUse: You want a simple language for fast onboarding.
Your project cannot tolerate slow builds.

guides.title: Functional Core
content: Keep pure logic in functions without side effects.
Push effects to the edges of the app.

tools.name: Python
tools.description: Versatile language with huge adoption across data, web, and automation.
whenNotToUse: You need maximum runtime performance.
You are building low-latency systems without native extensions.

guides.title: Project Layout
content: Keep a single source package folder.
Use a pyproject file to standardize tooling.

tools.name: JavaScript
tools.description: Web-first language with massive ecosystem and browser reach.
whenNotToUse: You need strict type guarantees without TypeScript.
You are building a compute-heavy backend without native help.

guides.title: Modern Tooling
content: Use a formatter and linter from day one.
Prefer ESM modules for consistency.

tools.name: CSS
tools.description: Core styling language for the web.
whenNotToUse: You need pixel-perfect PDFs without a rendering layer.
You are targeting environments without a CSS engine.

guides.title: Layout Basics
content: Default to flex or grid for layout.
Keep spacing on a consistent scale.

tools.name: Figma
tools.description: Collaborative UI design tool with real-time editing.
whenNotToUse: You need offline-only design workflows.
Your team relies heavily on native desktop integrations.

guides.title: Design Systems
content: Create reusable components early.
Name styles and tokens consistently.

tools.name: Unity
tools.description: Cross-platform game engine with a large community.
whenNotToUse: You need fully open-source engine control.
Your project targets ultra-small binary sizes.

guides.title: Project Setup
content: Lock editor version per project.
Use assembly definitions to keep compile times stable.

tools.name: VS Code
tools.description: Popular editor with strong extensions and multi-language support.
whenNotToUse: You need a fully offline, no-extension environment.
Your workflows rely on heavy IDE features only.

guides.title: Workspace Hygiene
content: Keep workspace settings in the repo.
Use extensions recommendations for team alignment.
